verses.text: About that time came Antiochus with dishonour out of the country of Persia.

For he had entered the \add city\add* called Persepolis, and went about to rob the temple, and to hold the city; whereupon the multitude running to defend themselves with \add their\add* weapons put them to flight; and \add so\add* it happened, that Antiochus being put to flight of the inhabitants returned with shame.
Now when he came to Ecbatana, news was brought him what had happened unto Nicanor and Timotheus.

Then swelling with anger, he thought to avenge upon the Jews the disgrace \add done unto him\add* by those that made him flee. Therefore commanded he \add his\add* chariot man to drive without ceasing, and to dispatch the journey, the judgment of God now following him. For he had spoken proudly in this sort, That he would come to Jerusalem, and make it a common burying place of the Jews.

But the Lord Almighty, the God of Israel, smote him with an incurable and invisible plague: for as soon as he had spoken \add these\add* words, a pain of the bowels \add that was\add* remediless came upon him, and sore torments of the inner \add parts;\add*
\add and that\add* most justly: for he had tormented other \add men\add*â€™s bowels with many and strange torments.

Howbeit he nothing at all ceased from \add his\add* bragging, but still was filled with pride, breathing out fire in \add his\add* rage against the Jews, and commanding to haste the journey: but it came to pass that he fell \add down\add* from \add his\add* chariot, carried violently; so that having a sore fall, all the members of \add his\add* body were much pained.

And \add thus\add* he that a little afore thought \add he\add* might command the waves of the sea, (so proud was he beyond the condition of man) and weigh the high mountains in a balance, was \add now\add* cast on the ground, and carried in a \add horse\add* litter, shewing forth unto all the manifest power of God.

So that the worms rose up out of the body of \add this\add* wicked \add man\add*, and whiles he lived in sorrow and pain, his flesh fell away, and the filthiness of his smell was noisome to all \add his\add* army.
And the \add man\add*, that thought a little afore \add he\add* could reach to the stars of heaven, no \add man\add* could endure to carry for \add his\add* intolerable stink.
Here therefore, being plagued, he began to leave off \add his\add* great pride, and to come to the knowledge \add of himself\add* by the scourge of God, \add his\add* pain increasing every moment.

And when he himself could not abide his own smell, he said these \add words\add*, \add It is\add* meet to be subject unto God, and that a \add man\add* that is mortal should not proudly think \add of himself\add*, as if he were God.
\add This\add* wicked \add person\add* vowed also unto the Lord, who now no more would have mercy upon him, saying thus,
That the holy city (to the which he was going in haste, to lay \add it\add* even with the ground, and to make \add it\add* a common burying place,) \add he\add* would set at liberty:

and \add as touching\add* the Jews, whom he had judged not worthy so much as to be buried, but to be cast out with \add their\add* children to be devoured of the fowls \add and\add* wild beasts, \add he\add* would make them all equals to the citizens of Athens:

and the holy temple, which before he had spoiled, \add he\add* would garnish with goodly gifts, and restore all the holy vessels with many more, and out of his own revenue defray the charges belonging to the sacrifices:
yea, and that also \add he\add* would become a Jew \add himself\add*, and go through all the world \add that was\add* inhabited, and declare the power of God.

But for all this \add his\add* pains would not cease: for the just judgment of God was come upon him: \add therefore\add* despairing of his health, he wrote unto the Jews the letter underwritten, containing the form of a supplication, after this manner:
Antiochus, king and governor, to the good Jews \add his\add* citizens \add wisheth\add* much joy, health, and prosperity:
If ye and \add your\add* children fare well, and your \add affairs\add* be to your contentment, I give very great thanks to God, having \add my\add* hope in heaven.

As for me, I was weak, \add or else\add* I would have remembered kindly your honour and good will. Returning out of Persia, and being taken with a grievous disease, I thought it necessary to care for the common safety of all:
not distrusting mine health, but having great hope to escape \add this\add* sickness.
But considering that even \add my\add* father, at what time he led an army into the high countries, appointed a successor,

to the end that, if any \add thing\add* fell out contrary to expectation, or if any \add tidings\add* were brought \add that were\add* grievous, they of the land, knowing to whom the state was left, might not be troubled:

again, considering how that the princes that are borderers and neighbours unto \add my\add* kingdom wait for opportunities, and expect what shall be the event, I have appointed my son Antiochus king, whom I often committed and commended unto many of you, when I went up into the high provinces; to whom I have written as followeth:
therefore I pray and request you to remember the benefits \add that I have done unto you\add* generally, and in special, and that every man will be still faithful to me and my son.
For I am persuaded that he understanding my mind will favourably and graciously yield to your desires.
Thus the murderer and blasphemer having suffered most grievously, as he entreated other \add men\add*, \add so\add* died he a miserable death in a strange \add country\add* in the mountains.
And Philip, that was brought up with him, carried away \add his\add* body, who also fearing the son of Antiochus went into Egypt to Ptolemeus Philometor.
